title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA organizations to remove a provider from an MA plan if the Secretary determines the provider is medically negligent or in violation of legal or contractual requirements. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA organizations to remove a provider from an MA plan if the Secretary determines the provider is unfit to furnish services in accordance with legal requirements, regardless of cost considerations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" permits MA organizations to eliminate a provider from an MA plan if the Secretary deems them unfit to provide services as required by law, regardless of cost considerations. Starting from the 2017 plan year, an MA organization can only remove a provider from a plan network for reasons not specified in the Act 60 days before the plan year begins. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA organizations to remove a provider from an MA plan if deemed unfit by the Secretary, with a notice and appeal process required before removal. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" mandates a fair notice and appeal process for MA organizations to remove providers from their network, requiring explanations for removal to be provided to the provider, supplier, and the Secretary. The process applies to removals occurring after the effective date of the final rule for the process. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" establishes a fair notice and appeal process for MA organizations to remove providers from their network. This process applies to removals occurring after the effective date of the final rule. The process for termination or suspension of a provider contract under section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations, applies to the removal of a provider from a Medicare Advantage plan network. The MA organization must give written notification of the removal to participants at least 60 days in advance. When a provider is removed from a Medicare Advantage plan network, the MA organization must notify enrolled individuals of the removal at least 60 days in advance. The notification should include the names and contact information of alternative in-network providers offering similar services. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in a Medicare Advantage plan at least 60 days in advance when a provider is removed from the network. The notification should include information on alternative in-network providers offering similar services, options for continuing treatment with the removed provider, and customer service telephone numbers. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in a Medicare Advantage plan at least 60 days in advance when a provider is removed from the network. This notification should also be included in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year. Additionally, continuity of care should be ensured for individuals affected by the provider's removal. The MA plan must notify members 60 days in advance of any provider removal from the network, ensuring continuity of care for affected individuals. Removals must meet continuity of care requirements for those receiving services during the current or previous plan year. Beginning with plan year 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan must provide transparency in measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This information must be included in the annual bid information submitted by the MA organization and on the Internet Web site for the MA plan. Beginning in 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency on measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This information includes details on quality and efficiency measures, methodology, and sample size. Beginning in 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency on measures used to establish or modify provider networks, including quality and efficiency measures, methodology, and sample size. The information provided should not include any individually identifiable information of any provider or supplier of services. Enforcement measures include sanctions for noncompliance with the requirements outlined in the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include sanctions for noncompliance with provider network transparency requirements by MA organizations. This includes failing to comply with specific sections and the expansion of applicable paragraphs in certain sections. The Social Security Act is amended to include sanctions for noncompliance with provider network transparency requirements by MA organizations, expanding applicable paragraphs in certain sections. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool considers the preferences and utilization needs of individuals within a year of this Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, and provider availability when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and timely provision of care when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must ensure timely provision of care by providers and adhere to network access adequacy standards set by the Secretary. Each year, organizations must certify that their MA plans include providers, including specialists. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations must certify that providers in their network can offer required services and meet enrollees' needs. They also need to report average wait times for each MA plan offered. Advantage organizations must report average wait times, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient for primary and specialty care under each MA plan. Certification is required before the annual coordinated election period. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify the accuracy of provider directories for each plan before the annual coordinated election period. The Secretary will review the network adequacy of each MA plan at least once every 3 years or when a material change in the network occurs. Enforcement is outlined in Section 1857(g)(1)(K) of the Social Security Act. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify provider directories annually.
